<Link id="l00001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===-- ARMFixCortexA57AES1742098Pass.cpp ---------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00003" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Part of the LLVM Project, under the Apache License v2.0 with LLVM Exceptions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This pass works around a Cortex Core Fused AES erratum:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Cortex-A57 Erratum 1742098</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Cortex-A72 Erratum 1655431</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The erratum may be triggered if an input vector register to AESE or AESD was</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// last written by an instruction that only updated 32 bits of it. This can</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// occur for either of the input registers.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The workaround chosen is to update the input register using &#96;r = VORRq r, r&#96;,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// as this updates all 128 bits of the register unconditionally, but does not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// change the values observed in &#96;r&#96;, making the input safe.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This pass has to be conservative in a few cases:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - an input vector register to the AES instruction is defined outside the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   current function, where we have to assume the register was updated in an</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   unsafe way; and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - an input vector register to the AES instruction is updated along multiple</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   different control-flow paths, where we have to ensure all the register</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   updating instructions are safe.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Both of these cases may apply to a input vector register. In either case, we</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// need to ensure that, when the pass is finished, there exists a safe</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instruction between every unsafe register updating instruction and the AES</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instruction.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00371" /><CodeLine lineNumber="371"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00372" /><CodeLine lineNumber="372"><span class="doxyHighlight">        </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// There is one unsafe defining instruction, which needs a fixup. It is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00373" /><CodeLine lineNumber="373"><span class="doxyHighlight">        </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// generally good to hoist the fixup to be adjacent to the defining</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00407" /><CodeLine lineNumber="407"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Insert the new &#96;VORRq qN, qN, qN&#96;. There are a few details here:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00408" /><CodeLine lineNumber="408"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00409" /><CodeLine lineNumber="409"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The uses are marked as killed, even if the original use of OperandToFixup</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00410" /><CodeLine lineNumber="410"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// is not killed, as the new instruction is clobbering the register. This is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00411" /><CodeLine lineNumber="411"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// safe even if there are other uses of &#96;qN&#96;, as the VORRq value-wise a no-op</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00412" /><CodeLine lineNumber="412"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (it is inserted for microarchitectural reasons).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00413" /><CodeLine lineNumber="413"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00414" /><CodeLine lineNumber="414"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The def and the uses are still marked as Renamable if the original register</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00415" /><CodeLine lineNumber="415"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// was, to avoid having to rummage through all the other uses and defs and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00416" /><CodeLine lineNumber="416"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// unset their renamable bits.</span></CodeLine>
